AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Many moons ago there was a folk tale passed down from generation to generation.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The story is about the Cho-Cho Man or the Boogie Man.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: It all began with a young boy named Dakota.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Dakota's mother had asked him to gather some firewood for the evening fire.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The nights were getting cooler.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Instead of doing the chore right away, Dakota figured he had enough sunlight left to do two things.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: He would gather the firewood after he played with his friends Morgan, Joey, and Bo.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Not long after, his mother began to wonder why Dakota never came with any firewood.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Night had fallen fast and it was too hard to see the firewood.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Dakota realized what had happened.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: He told his friends about his predicament and they said that they would help their friend.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Soon after, the young boys were gathering wood in the dark.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Dakota's mother was worried that something had happened.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: She went looking for Dakota.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Not long after, she heard the boys.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: She had mixed feelings.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: She was happy to see Dakota but she was also mad that he hadn't listened to his mother.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: She wanted to teach Dakota and his friends a lesson so she sneaked into the bush very quietly.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Then she picked up a twig and threw it.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The twig hit the ground making noise.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: It caught the boys' attention.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: She threw another broken twig in the opposite direction.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The boys jumped.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The mother had a hard time holding back her laughter and a muffled moan sounded through her fingers.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The boys were definitely scared.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: But Dakota was the brave one.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: He ventured forward.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The mother moaned again; she threw another twig.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The boys were transfixed.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Once more the mother moaned in a low and deep voice, "Listen to your mother."

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The boys dropped everything and ran.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: The mother could not hold back her laughter and the boys, hearing this, scurried home even faster.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: After the mother had picked up some firewood, she proceeded home, where she found Dakota in tears.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: Dakota exclaimed, "Mother, Mother I'm sorry I didn't listen to you."

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: His mother held him with love and she knew that he was truly sorry.

AUTHOR: Brenda Wright
TITLE: Always Listen
SENTENCE: From then on when Dakota felt like not listening, the mother would mention, "The boogie-man will scare you if you misbehave."

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora

SENTENCE: Every morning she would go to the park near the river to play with her friends.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: Mrs. Rabbit, Mr. Skunk and the very young deer were her best friends.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: One day they were playing together.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: They were having so much fun that they lost track of the time.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: The sun went down and it became dark.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: The little animals were afraid to go home alone.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: Princess Marina had an idea.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: She said, "Why don't you all come to my Grandpa's home with me. Grandpa doesn't mind it when I bring my friends to his place."

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: When Marina and her friends arrived at her grandpa's house her invited them in.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: He gave them all the treats that they could eat.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: After they ate they all played games.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: After a time Grandpa in a deep loud voice said, "It's time for bed now."

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: Grandpa gathered all the friends around and told them a bedtime story.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: Before long everyone was fast asleep.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: In the morning it was safe for the animals to go home.

AUTHOR: Henrique Figora
TITLE: The Forest Princess
SENTENCE: Everyday Marina and her friends still play but now they make sure that they go home before it gets dark.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: There was once a Miller, who, at his death, had nothing to leave to his three sons except his mill, his ass, and his cat.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The eldest son took the mill, the second took the ass and as for the youngest, all that remained for him was the cat.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The youngest son grumbled at this.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: My brothers, said he, "will be able to earn an honest living; but when I have eaten my cat and sold his skin I shall die of hunger."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat, who was sitting beside him, overheard this.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Nay, Master, he said, "don't take such a gloomy view of things. If you will get me a pair of boots made so that I can walk through the brambles without hurting my feet, and give me a bag, you shall soon see what I am worth."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat's master was so surprised to hear his Cat talking, that he at once got him what he wanted.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat drew on the boots and slung the bag round his neck and set off for a rabbit warren.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: When he got there he filled his bag with bran and lettuces, and stretching himself out beside it as if dead, waited until some young rabbit should be tempted into the bag.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: This happened very soon.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: A fat, thoughtless rabbit went in headlong, and the Cat at once jumped up, pulled the strings and killed him.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Puss was very proud of his success, and, going to the King's palace, he asked to speak to the King.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: When he was shown into the King's presence he bowed respectfully, and, laying the rabbit down before the throne, he said"Sire, here is a rabbit, which my master, the Marquis of Carabas, desires me to present to your Majesty."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Tell your master, said the King, "that I accept his present, and am very much obliged to him."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: A few days later, the Cat went and hid himself in a cornfield and laid his bag open as before.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: This time two splendid partridges were lured into the trap, and these also he took to the Palace and presented to the King from the Marquis of Carabas.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King was very pleased with this gift, and ordered the messenger of the Marquis of Carabas to be handsomely rewarded.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: For two or three months the Cat went on in this way, carrying game every day to the Palace, and saying it was sent by the Marquis of Carabas.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: At last the Cat happened to hear that the King was going to take a drive on the banks of the river, with his daughter, the most beautiful Princess in the world.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: He at once went to his master.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Master, said he, "if you follow my advice, your fortune will be made. Go and bathe in the river at a place I shall show you, and I will do the rest."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Very well, said the Miller's son, and he did as the Cat told him.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: When he was in the water, the Cat took away his clothes and hid them, and then ran to the road, just as the King's coach went by, calling out as loudly as he could"Help, help! The Marquis of Carabas will be drowned."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King looked out of the carriage window, and when he saw the Cat who had brought him so many fine rabbits and partridges, he ordered his bodyguards to fly at once to the rescue of the Marquis of Carabas.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Then the Cat came up to the carriage and told the King that while his master was bathing some robbers had stolen all his clothes.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King immediately ordered one of his own magnificent suits of clothes to be taken to the Marquis; so when the Miller's son appeared before the monarch and his daughter, he looked so handsome, and was so splendidly attired, that the Princess fell in love with him on the spot.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King was so struck with his appearance that he insisted upon his getting into the carriage to take a drive with them.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat, delighted with the way his plans were turning out, ran on before.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: He reached a meadow where some peasants were making hay.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Good people, said he, "if you do not tell the King, when he comes this way, that the meadow you are mowing belongs to the Marquis of Carabas, you shall all be chopped up into little pieces."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: When the King came by, he stopped to ask the haymakers to whom the meadow belonged.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: To the Marquis of Carabas, if it please Your Majesty, answered they, trembling, for the Cat's threat had frightened them terribly.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat, who continued to run before the carriage, now came to some reapers.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Good people, said he, "if you do not tell the King that all this corn belongs to the Marquis of Carabas, you shall all be chopped up into little pieces."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King again stopped to ask to whom the land belonged, and the reapers, obedient to the Cat's command, answered "To the Marquis of Carabas, please Your Majesty."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: And all the way the Cat kept running on before the carriage, repeating the same instructions to all the laborers he came to; so that the King became very astonished at the vast possessions of the Marquis of Carabas.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: At last the Cat arrived at a great castle, where an Ogre lived who was very rich, for all the lands through which the King had been riding were part of his estate.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Cat knocked at the castle door, and asked to see the Ogre.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Ogre received him very civilly, and asked him what he wanted.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: If you please, sir, said the Cat, "I have heard that you have the power of changing yourself into any sort of animal you please and I came to see if it could possibly be true."

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: So I have, replied the Ogre, and in a moment he turned himself into a lion.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: This gave the Cat a great fright, and he scrambled up the curtains to the ceiling.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: Indeed, sir, he said, "I am now quite convinced of your power to turn yourself into such a huge animal as a lion; but I do not suppose you can change yourself into a small one such as a mouse, for instance?"

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: "Indeed, I can," cried the Ogre, indignantly; and in a moment the lion had vanished, while a little brown mouse frisked about the floor.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: In less than half a second the Cat sprang down from the curtains and, pouncing upon the mouse, ate him all up before the Ogre had time to return to any other shape.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: And when the King arrived at the castle gates, there stood the Cat upon the doorstep, bowing and saying "Welcome to the castle of the Marquis of Carabas!"

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Marquis helped the King and the Princess to alight, and the Cat led them into a great hall, where a feast had been spread for the Ogre.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The King was so delighted with the good looks, the charming manners, and the great wealth of the Marquis of Carabas, that he said the Marquis must marry his daughter.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: The Marquis, of course, replied that he should be only too happy; and the very next day he and the Princess were married.

AUTHOR: Logan Marshall
TITLE: Puss in Boots
SENTENCE: As for the Cat, he was given the title of Puss-in-Boots, and ever after only caught mice for his own amusement.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Great good luck once happened to a young woman who was living all alone in the woods with nobody near her but her little dog; for, to her surprise, she found fresh meat every morning at her door.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She was very curious to know who it was that supplied her, and watching one morning, just as the sun had risen, she saw a handsome young man gliding away into the forest.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Having seen her, he became her husband, and she had a son by him.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: One day, not long after this, he did not return at evening, as usual, from hunting.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She waited till late at night, but he came no more.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The next day, she swung her child to sleep in its cradle, and then said to her dog, "Take care of your brother while I am gone, and when he cries, halloo for me."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The cradle was made of the finest wampum, and all its bandages and ornaments were of the same precious stuff.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: After a short time, the woman heard the cry of the dog, and running home as fast as she could, she found her child gone, and the dog too.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: On looking around, she saw scattered upon the ground pieces of the wampum of her child's cradle, and she knew that the dog had been faithful, and had striven his best to save her child from being carried off, as he had been, by an old woman, from a distant country, called Mukakee Mindemoea, or the Toad-Woman.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The mother hurried off at full speed in pursuit, and as she flew along, she came, from time to time, to lodges inhabited by old women, who told her at what time the child-thief had passed; they also gave her shoes that she might follow on.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: There was a number of these old women who seemed as if they were prophetesses, and knew what was to come long beforehand.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Each of them would say to her that when she had arrived at the next lodge, she must set the toes of the moccasins they had given her pointing homeward, and that they would return of themselves.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The young woman was very careful to send back in this manner all the shoes she borrowed.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She thus followed in the pursuit, from valley to valley, and stream to stream, for many months and years; when she came at length to the lodge of the last of the friendly old grandmothers, as they were called, who gave her the last instructions how to proceed.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She told her that she was near the place where her son was to be found; and she directed her to build a lodge of cedar-boughs, hard by the old Toad-Woman's lodge, and to make a little bark dish, and to fill it with the juice of the wild grape.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Then, she said, "your first child (meaning the dog) will come and find you out."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: These directions the young woman followed just as they had been given to her, and in a short time she heard her son, now grown up, going out to hunt, with his dog, calling out to him, "Peewaubik Spirit-Iron Twee! Twee!"

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The dog soon came into the lodge, and she set before him the dish of grape-juice.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: See, my child, she said, addressing him, "the pretty drink your mother gives you."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Spirit-Iron took a long draught, and immediately left the lodge with his eyes wide open; for it was the drink which teaches one to see the truth of things as they are.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: He rose up when he got into the open air, stood upon his hind legs, and looked about.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: I see how it is, he said; and marching off, erect like a man, he sought out his young master.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Approaching him in great confidence, he bent down and whispered in his ear (having first looked cautiously around to see that no one was listening), "This old woman here in the lodge is no mother of yours."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: I have found your real mother, and she is worth looking at.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: When we come back from our day's sport, I'll prove it to you.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: They went out into the woods, and at the close of the afternoon they brought back a great spoil of meat of all kinds.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The young man, as soon as he had laid aside his weapons, said to the old Toad-Woman, "Send some of the best of this meat to the stranger who has arrived lately."

SENTENCE: The Toad-Woman answered, "No! Why should I send to her, the poor widow!"

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The young man would not be refused; and at last the old Toad-Woman consented to take something and throw it down at the door.

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She called out, "My son gives you this."

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: But, being bewitched by Mukakee Mindemoea, it was so bitter and distasteful, that the young woman immediately cast it out of the lodge after her.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: In the evening the young man paid the stranger a visit at her lodge of cedar-boughs.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She then told him that she was his real mother, and that he had been stolen away from her by the old Toad-Woman, who was a child-thief and a witch.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: As the young man appeared to doubt, she added, "Feign yourself sick when you go home to her lodge; and when the Toad-Woman asks what ails you, say that you wish to see your cradle; for your cradle was of wampum, and your faithful brother the dog, in striving to save you, tore off these pieces which I show you."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: They were real wampum, white and blue, shining and beautiful; and the young man, placing them in his bosom, set off; but as he did not seem quite steady in his belief of the strange woman's story, the dog Spirit-Iron, taking his arm, kept close by his side, and gave him many words of encouragement as they went along.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: They entered the lodge together; and the old Toad-Woman saw, from something in the dog's eye, that trouble was coming.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews

SENTENCE: Oh, she answered, "it was a very bright, clear blue sky when you were born; that is the reason."

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: He seemed to be so very ill that the Toad-Woman at length asked what she could do for him.

SENTENCE: He said nothing could do him good but the sight of his cradle.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She ran immediately and brought a cedar cradle; but he said: "That is not my cradle."

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: When she had shown the four, and they had been all rejected, she at last produced the real cradle.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The young man saw that it was of the same stuff as the wampum which he had in his bosom.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: He could even see the marks of the teeth of Spirit-Iron left upon the edges, where he had taken hold, striving to hold it back.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: He had no doubt, now, which was his mother.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: To get free of the old Toad-Woman, it was necessary that the young man should kill a fat bear; and, being directed by Spirit-Iron, who was very wise in such a matter, he secured the fattest in all that country; and having stripped a tall pine of all its bark and branches, he perched the carcass in the top, with its head to the east and its tail due west.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: Returning to the lodge, he informed the old Toad-Woman that the fat bear was ready for her, but that she would have to go very far, even to the end of the earth, to get it.

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She answered: "It is not so far but that I can get it;" for of all things in the world, a fat bear was the delight of the old Toad-Woman.

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She at once set forth; and she was no sooner out of sight than the young man and his dog, Spirit-Iron, blowing a strong breath in the face of the Toad-Woman's four children (who were all bad spirits, or bear-fiends), they put out their life.

SENTENCE: They then set them up by the side of the door, having first thrust a piece of the white fat in each of their mouths.

TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: The Toad-Woman spent a long time in finding the bear which she had been sent after, and she made at least five and twenty attempts before she was able to climb to the carcass.

AUTHOR: Cornelius Mathews
TITLE: The Toad-Woman
SENTENCE: She slipped down three times where she went up once.
